metadata.title: Nd doped new oxyfluoro tellurite glasses and glass ceramics containing NaYF4 nano crystals − 1.06 μm emission analysis

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Luminescence
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jlumin
Nd3+ doped new oxyfluoro tellurite glasses and glass ceramics containing NaYF4 nano crystals − 1.06 µm emission analysis
Dagupati Rajesha,b,⁎, A.S.S. de Camargoa,⁎⁎
a São Carlos Institute of Physics, University of São Paulo, PO Box 369, 13560-970 São Carlos, SP, Brazil b Centre for Functional and Surface Functionalized Glass, Alexander Dubček University of Trenčin, Trenčin, Slovakia
A B S T R A C T
Oxyfluoro tellurite glasses with chemical composition TeO2-ZnO-YF3-NaF (TZYN), doped with Nd3+ in different concentrations were prepared by the melt-quenching technique. Judd–Ofelt analyses of Nd3+ ions in the precursor glasses were performed to evaluate the phenomenological intensity parameters Ω2,4,6. From the NIR emission spectra, characteristic parameters such as effective band with (Δλeff) and stimulated emission cross section (σP) were calculated for the three observed transitions, 4F3/2 → 4I9/2, 4I11/2 and 4I13/2 and compared to other reported glasses. Based on the luminescence decay times of 4F3/2 excited state, the quantum efficiency was evaluated and it is highest for a 0.2 mol% Nd3+ doped glass (G-Nd2). Glass ceramics were obtained by controlled heat treatment of the glasses at 390 °C for 5 h (as determined by DSC), which is greater than the glass transition temperature Tg. Moreover, DSC results revealed that precipitation of the NdYF4 nanocrystalline phase (TC1) decreased with increasing Nd3+ concentration. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) investigations reveal that spherical NaYF4 nano-crystals are distributed homogeneously across the glassy matrix. The emission intensity of the 4F3/2→4I11/2 transition at 1.60 µm was enhanced in glass ceramics as compared to glasses because of the occupancy of the Nd3+ in NaYF4 nanocrystlline phase. The experimental lifetime value of 4F3/2 also enhanced from 124 to 187 µs from G-Nd2 glass to GC-Nd2 glass ceramic and decreased with increasing Nd3+ concentration.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Glasses are quite interesting host matrices for rare earth ions and their properties have been investigated because of their potential technological applications in solid state lasers, optical detectors, solar concentrators, waveguide lasers, optical fibers for telecommunication and opto-electronics devices [1–4]. Moreover, glasses can be synthesized easily in several shapes and are found to act as stable laser host materials with high gain and minimum beam divergence. However, spectroscopic and optical properties of RE ions are highly sensitive to symmetry and the local structure at the rare earth sites, which can be altered by changing the chemical compositions of the host glass matrix [5,6]. Among the rare earth ions, Nd3+ is of particular technological interest owing to significantly intense NIR emission transitions at 0.9, 1.06 and 1.3 µm which can present with high efficiency, at room temperature [7,8]. In fact, Nd3+ doped glasses can be excited with bright pump sources in the ultraviolet to infrared spectral region because these glasses show well resolved fairly intense absorption peaks in all this range.
Among various kinds of oxide glass matrices available, tellurite glasses are predicated to be highly suitable for hosting lasing ions with such long wavelength emission. These glasses present high refractive index, wide transparency region (0.3–5 µm), low phonon energy (≈
800 cm−1), and low melting temperature [9]. When fluorine compounds are added into the tellurite glasses, they can offer important advantages over the pure fluoride or pure oxide compositions [10,11]. Neodymium oxide is less miscible in amorphous materials as compared to other rare earth oxides leadings to the formations of aggregates or clusters that can promote non-radiative de-excitation of Nd3+ through cross relaxations, resulting in shortage of excited state lifetimes [12]. It has been shown that the emission losses of Nd3+ due to cross relaxation can be minimized by mixtures with sesquioxides like Y2O3/Sc2O3. In this case, facilitated occupancy of Y3+, and Sc3+ sites by RE ions decease ion clustering in bulk glasses and, as a result, the average distance between the rare earth ions is increased. As a consequence, non-radiative losses owing to cross relaxation become less probable, increasing photoluminescence (PL) intensity [13]. Therefore, addition of Y3+/Sc3+ species in new oxyfluoro tellurite glasses is likely to imply more interesting and substantial improvement in the luminescence efficiency of Nd3+. Recently, we have studied Pr3+ ↔ Yb3+ energy transfer via quantum cutting and up-conversion in new oxyfluoro tellurite glass with composition TeO2-ZnO-YF3-NaF (TZYN), for solar cell applications [14].
Nowadays, the AREF4 (A, alkali metal and RE, rare earth) type crystalline phase is being extensively investigated in oxyfluoride transparent glasses, due to the promising luminescent properties of
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jlumin.2018.11.058 Received 21 August 2018; Received in revised form 27 November 2018; Accepted 29 November 2018
⁎ Corresponding authors at: São Carlos Institute of Physics, University of São Paulo, PO Box 369, 13560-970 São Carlos, SP, Brazil ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: andreasc@ifsc.usp.br (A.S.S. de Camargo).
Journal of Luminescence 207 (2019) 469–476
Available online 30 November 2018 0022-2313/ © 2018 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
these phases. For instance, de Pablos-Martín et al. [15] have synthesized the NaLaF4 crystal phase in a Tm3+ doped K2O–Na2O–Al2O3–SiO2–LaF3 glass by heat treatments slightly above the glass transition temperature, Tg. The corresponding glass-ceramic shows more intense blue up-conversion emission with respect to the parent glass. The crystallization of NaGdF4 in an oxyfluoride glass, and the partial incorporation of Sm3+ dopant ions in this phase, was reported by Herrmann et al. [16]. Furthermore, glass-ceramics containing NaYF4 nano crystals are also considered one of the most efficient hosts for up-conversion application [17–19] and which have been found potentially applicable in biological molecular labeling [20], and solar cells [21]. Usually NaYF4 possess two polymorphic forms, namely, αNaYF4 (cubic) and β-NaYF4 (hexagonal) [22]; the efficiency of the upconversion luminescence in hexagonal NaYF4 is at least one order of magnitude higher than in its cubic counterpart [23]. However, NaYF4 bulk crystal is difficult to grow due to the phase transition [24], which limits its application as bulk material in some fields such as luminescence device and solid-state lasers. Therefore, developing new glass ceramic containing NaYF4 nano-crystals is of great scientific and technical relevance. Several authors succeeded in the precipitation of NaYF4 nano crystals by heat treatment in silica based glass matrices [15,19,25–27] but there are no reports, to the best of our knowledge, on oxyfluoro tellurite glasses.
In the present study, we describe the optical properties of new oxyfluoro tellurite glasses and glass ceramics as a function of Nd3+
concentration. For glasses, by using absorption spectra and the least square fitting method, the Judd-Ofelt intensity parameters were calculated, as well as radiative lifetimes and branching ratios of certain excited states and transitions. From the emission spectra, stimulated emission cross section was calculated for three emission transitions and compared to other reported glasses. The quantum efficiency of the 4F3/2 excited state of Nd3+ ions was calculated from radiative and experimental lifetimes. The cubic phase of NaYF4 nanocrystals was precipitated in the glasses by controlled heat treatment, at proper temperature. The excitation spectra, NIR emission and decay curves were measured for all glass ceramics and the effect of NaYF4 nano crystalline phase precipitation on the emission intensities and lifetimes of the emitting 4F3/2 level is discussed.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
A series of different concentration of Nd3+ doped new oxyfluoro tellurite glasses having chemical composition (50-x) TeO2–30ZnO10YF3–10NaF-xNd2O3 (x= 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0mol%) were prepared by the conventional melt quenching method. For our convenience, these glasses will be addressed as G-Nd2, G-Nd5, G-Nd10 GNd15 and G-Nd20 for the respective 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0mol% concentrations of Nd3+. Te metal was converted in to TeO2 by heating up in air atmosphere at a temperature lower than that of melting. The appropriate amounts of chemical compounds with 99.9% purity viz., TeO2, ZnO, YF3, NaF and Nd2O3 (all in mol%) were mixed in an agate mortar and melted in platinum crucible placed in an electrical furnace at about 1050 °C, for about 45min till a bubble-free transparent liquid was formed. The resultant melt was poured into a preheated (200 °C) brass mould and transferred into an annealing furnace maintained at 250 °C to reduce the thermal stress. The obtained samples were polished for optical measurements. To obtain glass ceramics through crystallization, transparent glasses were heat-treated at 390 °C, which is the NaYF4 crystallization temperature determined by DSC (as shown in the results and discussion section), obtained with a heating rate of 10 °C/ min, for 5 h. For convenience, these samples will be addressed as GCNd2, GC-Nd5, GC-Nd10, GC-Nd15, and GC-Nd20 for our convenience. The samples GC-Nd2, GC-Nd5h, and GC-Nd10 are opaque in nature and the remaining are transparent (pictures not shown).
The density of the samples was measured by the Archimedes principle using a digital electronic weighing balance with xylene (0.861 g/
cm3) as the immersion liquid. The refractive index (nd) of glass samples were measured by prism coupling technique. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) profile of the G-Nd5 glass and the GC-Nd5 glass ceramic were measured in an X-ray diffractometer (ULTIMA IV, Rigaku) with Cu Kα radiation (1.54 Å) in the 2θ range 10–60°. Differential scanning calorimetry was measured for 30mg samples on a NETZSCH DSC-404 instrument, using a heating rate of 10 °C/min. UV−VIS−NIR absorption spectra of optically polished samples were measured in a Perkin Elmer spectrophotometer model Lambda 1050. Visible and Infrared excitation, emission, and excited-state lifetime measurements of Nd3+
doped glasses and glass ceramic were recorded using a Horiba Fluorolog spectrofluorometer, equipped with CW and pulsed Xe lamps as excitation sources. The signals were collected by a visible photodiode detector model PPD-850, and by an infrared Hamamatsu photomultiplier and Symphony II CCD. The spectra were all corrected by the lamp profile and detector's response.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Physical parameters
sections.text:
Different physical properties such as refractive index (n) at 543 nm,
density (d), thickness (t), average molecular weight (M), molar volume (Vm), ion concentration (N), dielectric constant (ε), optical dielectric constant, reflection loss (R) were obtained for all investigated glasses, doped with various Nd3+ concentrations, and are presented in Table 1 for G-Nd10 glass.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. XRD and DSC spectra
sections.text:
Fig. 1 depicts the XRD profile of G-Nd5 glass, which shows the two
dispersion peaks at approximately 28° and 53 °, characteristic of glass with completely amorphous nature.
Influence of Nd3+ concentration on TZYN glass with respect to the differential scanning calorimetric response (DSC) is depicted in Fig. 2 for G-Nd02, G-Nd10 and G-Nd20 glasses. As it can be seen, three temperature parameters could be identified such as (i) glass transition temperature (Tg), located at 336, 348 and 357 °C, (ii) the crystallization onset temperature (Tx), at 378, 427 and 453 °C, and (iii) two peaks of crystallization temperatures (Tc2 & Tc3), at 425 & 510, 456 & 485, 480 & 520 °C for G-Nd2, G-Nd10 and G-Nd20 glasses, respectively. It is noticed that Tg is enhanced by 20 °C with increasing Nd3+ concentration, which may be due to the increase in the viscosity of the melt with concentration. Moreover, a unique crystallization peak (Tc1) around 390 °C is observed and it descends with Nd3+ concentration. Furthermore, crystallization peaks temperature (Tc2 & Tc3) shift towards higher temperature with increasing Nd3+ concentration, revealing that crystallization demotes with Nd3+ concentration. The difference between Tx and Tg is called thermal stability and it is 42, 79 and 96 °C for GNd02, G-Nd10 and G-Nd20 glasses, respectively, indicating that thermal stability increases with Nd3+ concentration.

sections.heading: S. No Physical parameter G-Nd10 glass
3.1.3. Absorption spectra and Judd-ofelt parameters
sections.text:
Except for differences in intensities, the absorption spectra in the
UV–VIS–NIR range of as prepared glasses are quite similar with regards to line shape band positions. Fig. 3 depicts the representative spectrum for G-Nd10 glass. As we can see, the spectrum consists of ten bands centered at 432, 472, 512, 526, 584, 627, 683, 747, 803 and 875 nm, which can be associated with transitions from the ground state 4I9/2 to the various excited states 2P1/2, 2G9/2 +2D3/2 +4G11/2, 4G9/2, 4G7/2
+ 2K13/2, 4G5/2 +2G7/2, 2H11/2, 4F9/2, 4S3/2 +4F7/2, 4F5/2 +2H9/2 and 4F3/2 of Nd3+ ion, respectively. Among these, 4I9/2→2P1/2 is observed to be feeble. The 4I9/2 → 4G5/2 transition is found to be more intense because the selection rules viz., ΔJ ≤ 2; ΔL ≤ 2; ΔS = 0, are obvious valid for this transition. The higher values of ‖U‖2 for this transition are also predicted to be responsible for the hyper sensitive nature of this level [28]. Judd–Ofelt [29,30] theory is a useful tool to analyze the spectral properties of rare earth doped glasses or crystals. As known, the magnetic dipole contribution to the total spectral intensities is negligible since they are independent from the ligand field provided by the different hosts. Therefore, all the absorption transitions are assumed to be of induced electric dipole nature and magnetic dipole contributions were disregarded in calculating the phenomenological Judd-Ofelt (J-O) parameters [31]. The experimental (fexp) an d calculated (fcal) oscillator strenghts and the J-O intensity parameters (Ωλ, λ=2, 4 and 6) were calculated for G-Nd10 glass by using suitable expressions given in Ref. [32]. The values are presented in Table 2 and Table 3, along with values reported for other glasses [33–39]. From Table 2, it is noted that there is no abnormal variations in the magnitude of spectral intensities of observed absorption transitions, as compared to other reported glasses [33,34]. The rms deviation gives an idea about the quality of the fit and its values are quite good for all the fitted curves. Usually, Ω2 is related to the asymmetry and covalence between the rare earth ions and the ligand anions, while Ω4 and Ω6 reflect the bulk properties of the host, such as rigidity and density [40,41]. As it can be seen from Table 3, the J-O parameters are similar to the other reported values and the magnitude increases in the order Ω2> Ω6> Ω4. The Ω2 is found to be greater than other reported values, except for TNLNNd10 [33], which may be due to a higher value of the hypersensitive 4I9/2→ 4G5/2 transition intensity. The high value of Ω2 in TZYN glass indicates that the host glass exhibit higher covalence and asymmetry as compared with other glass hosts. The emission intensities of 4F3/2 → 4IJ (J=9/2, 11/2, 13/2) transitions are uniquely characterized by the Ω4/Ω6 ratio, known as the spectroscopic quality factor (χ) [42,43].
The increase in the χ factor value usually implies an increase in fluorescence efficiency of the 4F3/2 → 4I11/2 transition. From Table 3, it can be seen that, the χ value for G-Nd10 glass is found to be 0.77, which is in between the other values reported for Nd3+ doped glasses [33–39]. Therefore, in the investigated glasses, the intensity of the 4F3/2 → 4I11/2 transition suggests the possibility of laser action at 1059 nm.

sections.heading: 3.1.4. Radiative properties and emission spectra
sections.text:
The obtained J-O parameters and refractive index were further used
to compute the radiative parameters such as radiative transition probabilities (AR), branching ratios (βR), and radiative lifetimes (τrad, μs) for the G-Nd10 glass, which are tabulated in Table 4.
Fig. 4 shows typical photoluminescence (PL) NIR emission spectra of the TZYN glasses doped with variable concentration of Nd3+, measured upon excitation at 575 nm. The emission spectra exhibits three prominent emission bands centered at 900, 1059 and 1333 nm corresponding to the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2, 4I11/2 and 4I13/2 transitions, respectively. Out of these, the emission band due to 4F3/2 → 4I11/2 transition corresponds to a hypersensitive transition with higher intensity as compared to the other two bands. Moreover, an intensity enhancement of all the bands is observed up to 0.5 mol% and beyond that there is a progressive decrease. This is attributed to the large number of Nd3+ ions in the glass matrix, which transfer excitation energy to the nearby Nd3+ ions through the cross relaxation processes 4F3/2: 4I9/2 → 4I15/2: 4I15/2 or 4F3/ 2: 4I9/2 → 4I13/2: 4I15/2, and also between resonant energy channels [43] as shown in Fig. 5. This energy transfer effect leads to a phenomenon related to as concentration quenching. To further confirm the dependence of emission bands intensity variation with Nd3+ concentration, we measured the photoluminescence excitation spectra (PLE) for all investigated glass matrices monitoring the emission at 1060 nm as presented in Fig. 6. It is noticed that, intensity variation of excitation bands with Nd3+ concentration is in good agreement with the data
obtained from the emission spectra. From the emission spectra, emission peak wavelength (λP), effective linewidth (Δλeff), experimental branching ratio (βexp) and stimulated emission cross-section (σp) were computed for the observed emission transitions in all glass matrices and are presented in Table 5 along with the branching ratio (βR) and radiative transition probability (AR). In fact, stimulated emission cross-section (σp) is dependent on the J-O intensity parameters and effective bandwidths (Δλeff) of the emission
bands, which are affected by host glass matrices. In addition, the emission band at 1059 nm due to 4F3/2 → 4I11/2 transition depends only on Ω4 and Ω6 parameters [44]. Moreover, a branching ratio (β > 50%) is also a critical parameter to characterize the possibility of attaining stimulated emission from any specific transition. From Table 5, for 4F3/2 → 4I11/2 transition, experimental (βexp) and radiative (βR) branching ratios are greater than 0.5 and stimulated emission cross section is found to be higher, as compared to the remaining two transitions. The G-Nd5 glass possess higher stimulated emission cross section than the

TNKNd10 [33], TeO2-Nb2O5:Nd2O3 [46], LG-770 [47], and LG-750 [47], reported glasses and lower than the TNLNd10 [33], TeO2LiF:Nd2O3 [45], PKMAN10 [31], PKMAFN10 [31], and PKMABFN10 [31] glasses, shown in Table 6. However, for efficient lasers, in addition to high σP, the gain bandwidth parameter (Δλeff × σP) should also be as high as possible to attain high gain and the values are higher for the GNd5 glass as compared to other reported glass, except PKMABFN10 [31], as shown in Table 6. These results suggest that G-Nd05 glass can be used as an efficient laser emitter at 1059 nm.

sections.heading: 3.1.5. Decay curves
sections.text:
The luminescence decay curves from the 4F3/2 level of Nd3+ ion were recorded at room temperature upon excitation at 575 nm and by monitoring at 1059 nm emission. Fig. 7 depicts the Nd3+ concentration
dependent decay profiles for all investigated glasses. All the decay curves are well fitted to single exponential functions except for the decay curve of G-Nd20 glass, which is non-exponential in nature. The single exponential nature of these decay curves (except for G-Nd20) is due to either fast decay of excited Nd3+ ions or the effect of ligands is considerably small on Nd3+ ions. From the decay curves, the experimental lifetime (τexp) values for the 4F3/2 level were determined by using the following expression [48]
∫
∫ =τ tI t dt I t dt ( ) ( )exp (1)
where I (t) is the emission intensity at time t. The τexp values of 4F3/2 are found to be 124, 92, 59, 49, and 39 μs for G-Nd2, G-Nd5, G-Nd10, GNd15 and G-Nd20 glasses, respectively. It is noted that, τexp decreases by increasing the Nd3+ concentration. The obtained experimental decay time (τexp) values for the investigated glasses are comparable to those of the TNKNd10 (144 μs) [33], and TBiZNd05 (152 μs) [49] glasses. The quantum efficiency (η) of the 4F3/2 excited state, is defined as the ratio of experimental and calculated radiative lifetimes (τexp/ τrad) and is found to be 71.67%, 53.17%, 34.10%, 28.32%, and 22.54% for G-Nd2, G-Nd5, G-Nd10, G-Nd15 and G-Nd20 glasses, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. XRD, FE-SEM and TEM
sections.text:
The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of GC-Nd5 glass ceramic is
shown in Fig. 1. As it can be seen, after heat-treatment, intense diffraction peaks are observed, which are attributed to cubic NaYF4, JCPDS: 06–0342 [50]. According to the Ostwald's step rule, the least stable polymorph, α-NaYF4 is formed first in systems far from thermodynamic equilibrium. This phenomenon is observed in several oxyfluoride glass ceramics in additions to the present system [25–27]. Moreover, two impurity diffraction peaks are clearly observed around 24° and 29° owing to TeO2 (JCPDS: 041–0945) [51]. The mean crystallite size is calculated by Scherrer formula based on the major intensity peak widths is about 19 nm. The field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) image of GC-Nd5 glass ceramic, shown in Fig. 8, demonstrated that NaYF4 particles are spherical in nature, sized around 17 nm and homogeneously distributed in the glass matrix.
The TEM micrograph and corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns of GC-Nd5 sample are displayed in Fig. 9a and (b), respectively. The TEM allows the direct imaging of nanoparticles and provides some information on the quality of individual particles including their sizes and distributions. As it can be seen, the dark and nearly spherical particles correspond to NaYF4 nanocrystals,

sections.heading: 4F3/2 → 4I9/2 900 40.35 2310.3 0.40 0.15 1.37
sections.text: which are random and homogeneously dispersed in the glassy host. The average size of NaYF4 nanocrystal is found to be 20 nm, which is consistent with the value obtained from SEM. In addition, the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image shown in Fig. 9(c) reveals the high crystalline nature of the as-prepared nanocrystals and displays the resolved lattice fringes of NaYF4 nanocrystals.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Excitation and emission spectra
sections.text:
The excitation spectrum for GC-Nd5 glass ceramic was recorded
monitoring the emission wavelength 1060 nm and is depicted in Fig. 10 along with the spectrum of G-Nd5 glass. In order to able to compare the luminescence intensity scale of glasses and glass ceramics, we made our best to take the measurements at the same conditions with the samples of very similar size. As it can be seen, the bands position observed in glass ceramics are same as the observed in G-Nd5 glass (see Section 3.1.4) and remarkable enhancement in excitation intensity is noticed for GC-Nd5 glass ceramic compared to that of G-Nd5 glass. Moreover, excitation bands between 700 and 900 nm possess stark splitting due to the presence of the crystalline phase, which consequently modifies the environment of the Nd3+ ion. For instance, the excitation bands at 803 and 880 nm change in shape after heat treatment and there are narrow peaks located at 820, 833 and 870, 892 nm, respectively. In addition to
that, at the 747 nm excitation band, the intensity of the shoulder at 738 nm slightly increases compared to that of the main band at 747 nm, which indicates that heat treatment has an impact on the Nd3+ excitation bands.
Fig. 11 depicts the NIR emission spectra for G-Nd05 glass and glass ceramics measured upon excitation at 800 nm. It is worthwhile noting that the intensity of emission bands is higher for GC-Nd2, GC-Nd5 and GC-Nd10 glass ceramics as compared to G-Nd5 glass. Moreover, among glass ceramics, emission intensity is higher for GC-Nd2 and then tends to diminish with Nd3+ concentration increase. The reason for that is a decrease in precipitation of NaYF4 phase by increasing the Nd3+ concentration. However, intensity remains the same for GC-Nd15 and GNd15 & GC-Nd20 and G-Nd20 species, respectively, not show in Fig. 11. This could be due to no precipitation of NaYF4 nano crystals even after heat treatment. Intensity variation of emission transitions in glass ceramics with respect to Nd3+ concentration is well consistent with the DSC results as we discussed in Section 3.1.2. It has been reported that, for Er3+ doped silicate based glass ceramics, intensity enhancement in emission bands is attributed to the precipitation of NaYF4 nano crystals and incorporation of Er3+ ions into low phonon NaYF4 nano crystalline phase [19,52]. But in the present case, we believe that NaYF4 stays in the amorphous phase and may be small part of it end up in the
crystalline phase. To know about this, we need to perform more structural characterization studies.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Decay time measurements
sections.text:
The fluorescence lifetime of rare earth ions is sensitive to the environment around the rare earth ion. The decay profiles for 4F3/2 state of Nd3+ ions in glass ceramics with different Nd3+ concentration were measured by monitoring the wavelength of 4F3/2→4I11/2 transition and are shown in Fig. 12. It is noted that all decay curves are single exponential in nature and excited state lifetime values were determined by fitting the first e-folding times of the decay intensity.
The decay was slower for GC-Nd2, GC-Nd5, and GC-Nd10 glass ceramics than for the G-Nd2, G-Nd5, and G-Nd10 glasses, respectively, and the lifetime, obviously higher. Moreover, lifetime values decrease from 187 to 35 μs with increasing Nd3+ concentration, as shown in the inset of Fig. 12, because there is a decreased in the precipitation of NaYF4 nano crystals.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, new oxyfluoro tellurite glasses and glass ceramics doped with variable concentration of Nd3+ ions have been prepared by melt quenching technique and subsequent heat treatment of the precursor glasses, respectively. From the optical absorption spectra, intensities of various absorption bands were computed and found to be higher for the hypersensitive transitions 4I9/2 → 4G5/2 + 2G7/2, which induces higher values for the J-O parameter Ω2 as compared to the
values for other reported tellurite glasses. The properties indicating potential laser action such as effective fluorescence bandwidth (Δλeff) and emission cross-section (σP) were investigated and the respective values are 31.57 nm and 4.19×10–20 cm2 for G-Nd5 glass. These values are found to be comparable with those of others reported Nd3+
doped glasses. FE-SEM and TEM analysis reveals that NaYF4 nano crystals are homogeneously distributed in the glass matrix and the calculated average particle size is about 20 nm. The intensity of emission transitions and decay lifetime for 4F3/2 state of Nd3+ ions in glass ceramics are found to depend on Nd3+ concentration. This could be ascribed to a decrease in the precipitation of NaYF4 nano crystals owing to perhaps either Nd3+ ions may not have well nucleating effect in this glasses or higher amount of Nd3+ concentration do not favor the crystallization of these glasses. Overall, the results suggest TZYN: Nd3+
glass is potential candidate for solid state laser applications.

metadata.abstractText: Oxyfluoro tellurite glasses with chemical composition TeO2-ZnO-YF3-NaF (TZYN), doped with Nd in different concentrations were prepared by the melt-quenching technique. Judd–Ofelt analyses of Nd ions in the precursor glasses were performed to evaluate the phenomenological intensity parameters Ω2,4,6. From the NIR emission spectra, characteristic parameters such as effective band with (Δλeff) and stimulated emission cross section (σP) were calculated for the three observed transitions, F3/2 → I9/2, I11/2 and I13/2 and compared to other reported glasses. Based on the luminescence decay times of F3/2 excited state, the quantum efficiency was evaluated and it is highest for a 0.2 mol% Nd doped glass (G-Nd2). Glass ceramics were obtained by controlled heat treatment of the glasses at 390 °C for 5 h (as determined by DSC), which is greater than the glass transition temperature Tg. Moreover, DSC results revealed that precipitation of the NdYF4 nanocrystalline phase (TC1) decreased with increasing Nd concentration. X-ray diffraction (XRD) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) investigations reveal that spherical NaYF4 nano-crystals are distributed homogeneously across the glassy matrix. The emission intensity of the F3/2→I11/2 transition at 1.60 μm was enhanced in glass ceramics as compared to glasses because of the occupancy of the Nd in NaYF4 nanocrystlline phase. The experimental lifetime value of F3/2 also enhanced from 124 to 187 μs from G-Nd2 glass to GC-Nd2 glass ceramic and decreased with increasing Nd concentration.
